Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spectra of Linear Differential Operators and Turbulence in Integrable Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nonlinear evolution equations, also known as soliton equations, are used to model a wide variety of physical systems, such as ocean waves or fiber optic communications. Many such equations, for example the Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) equation for waves in shallow water, have the exciting feature that many of their solutions can be given exactly by an explicit formula. This allows one to develop a precise understanding of the underlying physical processes. However, the range of conditions for which exact solutions are currently known is restrictive, inhibiting the use of such solutions in real-world applications. This project aims to find larger families of exact solutions to soliton equations, and use these solutions to develop statistical theories of the corresponding physical systems.
 
The main goal of the project is to construct and study new families of solutions of soliton equations such as KdV, Nonlinear Schrödinger, and Kadomtsev-Petviashvili. These solutions are obtained as limits of multisoliton solutions, and are bounded and non-decreasing at infinity. They are described by a Riemann-Hilbert problem and can be efficiently computed numerically. The first goal is a rigorous mathematical description of these new solutions. The PIs will investigate to what extent these solutions solve the initial value problem for KdV and related systems. They will study spectral properties of the associated linear operators and construct non-periodic one-dimensional ideal conductors. Finally, the PIs will develop a statistical theory of integrable turbulence for KdV and other soliton equations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of integrable systems studies nonlinear physical models that can be solved exactly. A characteristic property of an integrable system is the existence of infinitely many conserved quantities. A classical example of an integrable system is the Korteweg-de Vries (KdV) equation, which describes one-dimensional waves on shallow water. The theory of the KdV equation is closely linked to the spectral theory of the one-dimensional Schroedinger operator, which has fundamental importance in quantum mechanics.

In previous work, the PI defined a broad class of solutions of the KdV equations, called primitive solutions. The KdV equation admits a family of rapidly decreasing solutions called multisoliton solutions, and primitive solutions are obtained as the limit of multisoliton solutions with infinitely many solitons. The spectral properties of primitive solutions are identical to those of periodic and quasi-periodic finite-gap solutions of KdV, and it was shown in the project that the latter are examples of the former. For fixed moments of time, primitive solutions represent one-dimensional nonperiodic ideal conductors (the DNA molecule has a similar property). In addition, primitive solutions were generalized to include limits of arbitrary rapidly decaying solutions of KdV. Primitive solutions can be considered as examples of one-dimensional integrable turbulence.

A primitive solution of KdV is described by a pair of functions called the dressing functions. When these functions are equal, the PI showed that the primitive solution can be constructed explicitly as an appropriate power series. It turns out that all periodic finite-gap solutions of KdV can be described by this method.

The PI also constructed a new family of solutions for the KP-I equation, which is a two-dimensional generalization of the KdV equation. These solutions consist of chains of localized lumps, which are arranged in evolving polygonal patterns, and can also form complex quasiperiodic chains. The PI also constructed a family of solutions for the Kaup-Broer integrable system.

An important example of a physical system in hydrodynamics is an incompressible fluid with infinite depth and a free surface. A longstanding conjecture of the PI states that this system is integrable. Proving this conjecture would be a monumental result, allowing the application of methods of integrable systems to hydrodynamics. The PI's results give strong support for this conjecture. Specifically, the PI and coauthors constructed an infinite family of conserved quantities for this system, and described the formation of droplets on the fluid surface.
